title: 111_hr2991
content:
The Act titled "Department of Transportation Bonding Assistance Authority Act of 2009" allows the Secretary to guarantee surety against loss from a principal's breach of bond. The Act allows the Secretary to guarantee surety against loss resulting from a breach of bid, payment, performance bonds by a principal, with specific conditions for eligibility. The Secretary can guarantee a surety against loss from avoiding a breach of bond terms, with specific conditions for eligibility and indemnification provisions. The Secretary can guarantee a surety against loss from avoiding a breach of bond terms. Conditions for eligibility include the Secretary determining imminent breach, approval required for payments, a payment limit of 10% of the contract price unless deemed necessary by the Secretary, and payments not exceeding the surety's guaranteed share of the bond. The Secretary can reimburse the surety for up to 90% of the loss incurred, with no duplicate payments allowed. The reimbursement is subject to certain conditions, and the Secretary may be relieved of liability under specific circumstances. The Secretary may establish regulations for participating sureties regarding underwriting, claim practices, and loss ratios. The Secretary can also adopt a procedure for reimbursing sureties for paid losses, with adjustments made after disbursement. The Secretary requires participating sureties to make reports and allows audits of their documents and records. Sureties are audited at least once every three years. The Secretary administers this subsection prudently and economically. The Secretary administers the program prudently and economically, establishing fees for small businesses and premiums for sureties. A State program allows selected States to carry out activities related to issuing guarantees and assisting small businesses. The Secretary oversees the program efficiently, setting fees for small businesses and premiums for sureties. Selected states must meet prescribed assessments and standards, submit annual reports on program details, guarantees provided, and participation of small businesses. The Secretary is required to submit an annual report to specific committees detailing program activities. Definitions include 'bid bond' as a bond for contract bidders. Definitions for the program include a 'bid bond' for contract bidders and eligibility criteria for small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals, service-disabled veterans, or qualified HUBZone entities. The curr_chunk provides definitions for terms related to bid bonds, including the definition of a qualified HUBZone small business concern and a small business concern owned and controlled by women. The term 'obligee' is also defined in relation to bid, payment, and performance bonds. Surety runs in the event of a breach by the principal of the conditions of a payment bond or performance bond. A payment bond is for the principal to pay money to persons under contract, while a performance bond is for the completion of a contract. The prime contractor is the person contracted to perform the work, and the principal is the person primarily liable for completing the contract or making payments. The term 'surety' refers to the person or state that undertakes to pay a sum of money to the obligee in case the principal breaches the conditions of a payment or performance bond. The Secretary of Transportation is defined as the Secretary, acting through the Minority Resource Center. A subcontractor is a person who has contracted with a prime contractor or another subcontractor to perform a contract. The term 'surety' refers to the person or state that undertakes to pay a sum of money to the obligee in case the principal breaches the conditions of a bond, contract, or payment. This includes performance bonds, payment bonds, and acting as an agent or underwriter. Authorization of appropriations is provided to the Secretary for implementation. Authorization of appropriations is provided to the Secretary for implementation, with $50,000,000 authorized for each fiscal year from 2010 to 2014, with a limit of $20,000,000 for activities under paragraph (8). SEC. 3. NATIONAL INFORMATION CLEARINGHOUSE.

Amends Section 332(b)(1) of title 49, United States Code to include "any Federal, State, or local mode of transportation".
